		     Privacy Policy Thank you Your message has been sent. Sorry There was an error emailing this page. By Lucian Constantin Romania Correspondent, IDG News Service | Apr 11, 2017 8:58 AM PT Credit: Peter Sayer More like this To punish Symantec, Google may distrust a third of the web's SSL certificates After Digital Certificate Hack, Mozilla Seeks Reassurances HTTPS Is Under Attack Again Video Why You Lost Your Windows 10 Product Key In a few months, publicly trusted certificate authorities will have to start honoring a special Domain Name System (DNS) record that allows domain owners to specify who is allowed to issue SSL certificates for their domains. The Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) DNS record became a standard in 2013¬†but didn't have much¬†of a real-world impact because certificate authorities (CAs) were under no obligation to conform to them. The record allows a domain owner to list the CAs that are allowed to issue SSL/TLS certificates for that domain. The reason for this is to limit cases of unauthorized certificate issuance, which can be accidental or intentional, if a CA is compromised or has a rogue employee. [ Further reading: How the new age of antivirus software will protect your PC ] Under existing industry rules created by the CA/Browser Forum, an organization that combines major browser vendors and CAs, certificate authorities must validate that requests for SSL certificates originate from domain owners themselves or from someone in control of those domains. This ownership verification is typically automated and involves asking the domain owner to create a DNS TXT record with a specific value or to upload authorization codes at a specific location in their site's structure, thus proving their control over the domain. However, hacking into a website could also give an attacker the ability to pass such verifications and request a valid certificate for the compromised domain from any certificate authority. Such a certificate could later be used to launch man-in-the-middle attacks against users or to direct them to phishing pages. The goal behind the CAA record is to limit who can issue certificates for a domain. For example, Google's CAA record is: google.com 86400 IN CAA 0 issue "symantec.com." This means that Google specifically authorizes Symantec to issue certificates for its main domain name. In March, the CA/B Forum voted to make CAA record checking mandatory as part of the certificate issuing process. This requirement will go into effect on Sept. 8, and CAs that will fail to honor these records will be in violation of industry rules and will risk sanctions. In addition to the "issue" tag, the CAA record also supports a tag called "iodef" that will also be mandatory for CAs to comply with. This tag allows the domain owner to specify an email address or a URL where CAs can report certificate issuing requests that conflict with the domain's CAA policy. For example, if one CA receives a request for a certificate for domain X, but domain X has a CAA record that authorizes a different CA to issue certificates, the first CAmust report the suspicious request to the email address or the URL specified in the CAA iodef property. This will alert the domain owner that someone else might be trying to obtain a certificate without authorization. "CAA is not a silver bullet, but it is another layer in our defense," Scott Helme, a security researcher and HTTPS deployment expert, said in a blog post. "We don't have to worry about vendor lock because the record is only checked at the point of issuance, and it couldn't be simpler to setup. There's really nothing to lose." To comment on this article and other PCWorld content, visit our Facebook page or our Twitter feed. Related: Security Encryption Privacy Websites Lucian Constantin is an IDG News Service correspondent. He writes about information security, privacy, and data protection. People folders in Google Photos are disappearing for some, Google is on the case Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/04/16 3:11pm PDTApr 16, 2017 36 Plus 1 on G+ 73 Share on Facebook 55 Share on Twitter Total Shares164 Applications Bug Watch Google News This holiday weekend might result in some slightly disorganized photos. The automatically created "People" folders in Google Photos are disappearing for some people. At least now you'll have some kind of excuse not to have to show your great-aunt pictures of your kids egg-hunting. It looks like the trouble cropped up sometime in the last few days. Google has already let people that reported the problem on their forum know that it is aware of the issue and is looking for a fix. To see if you've been affected hop on Google Photos and check your "People" album. If you see expected faces missing you're either one of the unlucky ones, or your parents' date at the school dance back in 1955 isn't going too well. In the meantime, if you discover that you are among those experiencing the problem, now you know Google is hot on the case. Should they provide an update on the forums relating to the trouble then we'll be sure to let you know. Source: Google (1, 2, 3) Tags google+ photos Great Scott Photos People Disappearing Photos People Missing Photos Problem subscribe ... Posted on April 17, 2017, 00:00 GMT Nitasha Tiku BuzzFeed News Reporter Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On vk Share On vk Share Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Pin Share On lineapp Share On lineapp Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Share On email Share On email Share On sms Share On sms Share On whatsapp Share On whatsapp Share On more Share On more Share On more Share On more More Share On tumblr Share On tumblr Share On stumbleupon Share On stumbleupon Share On linkedin Share On linkedin Share On reddit Share On reddit Share On googleplus Share On googleplus Share On link Share On link Until recently, Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs most iconic public appearance may have been the image of the young startup founder sweating through his hoodie onstage while journalist Kara Swisher grilled him at a tech conference in 2010. But Zuckerberg‚Äôs reputation as someone averse to the hot seat began a couple years earlier, on 60 Minutes. In the segment, anchor Lesley Stahl tells a 23-year-old Zuckerberg he‚Äôs replaced Google cofounders Larry Page and Sergey Brin as the tech exec that ‚Äúeveryone is talking about.‚Äù In response, the CEO of Facebook says nothing, his face placid. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just staring at me,‚Äù says Stahl. ‚ÄúIs that a question?‚Äù Zuckerberg shoots back. Cue the voiceover: ‚ÄúWe were warned that he can be awkward and reluctant to talk about himself.‚Äù Zuckerberg, now a 32-year-old dad with one daughter and another on the way, has evolved considerably in the intervening decade. He hired speechwriters. He spruced up his uniform from Valley schlub to monochrome minimalism. He took on a series of annual self-improvement challenges that made him into a ‚Äúlifestyle guru‚Äù for some male tech workers, according to the New York Times Style section. (The paper said his announcements ‚Äúsometimes have the feel of software upgrades,‚Äù but disciples admire Zuckerberg‚Äôs ability to reinvent himself ‚Äúas a better human being.‚Äù) ‚ÄúOne of the things I‚Äôve noticed over the years, he has improved his EQ,‚Äù Swisher told BuzzFeed News. (EQ is shorthand for emotional quotient, a popular rubric for measuring interpersonal skills in Silicon Valley.) ‚ÄúHe was super, super awkward to talk to and he knew that he had a problem and he was fully aware. He cared about changing it.‚Äù He may even have challenged himself to improve. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really shy, I should learn not to be so shy! I can see him saying that,‚Äù Swisher said. Now, Zuckerberg is even leading the charge for Silicon Valley tech CEOs who, post-election, have committed to leaving their bubble and interacting with the American public. He‚Äôs actively inserting himself into unfamiliar situations. This time around, however, Zuckerberg has cut out the media middleman. He‚Äôs communicating with people through his own platform, where he has amassed 88 million Facebook followers. And he‚Äôs not just talking to them about Facebook ‚Äî he‚Äôs talking to them about himself. The most obvious example of the new and improved Zuckerberg is his 2017 personal challenge: to travel to all 50 states and talk to ‚Äúfolks‚Äù about their lives and concerns for the future. Four months in, he is making good time on his vow. He‚Äôs already visited an oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico, sampled BBQ in Baton Rouge, and petted a baby longhorn ("so cute") at a rodeo in Ft. Worth. Oftentimes the themes of these visits coincide with those in the 6,000-word letter that he posted in February arguing in favor of building a global community (and Facebook‚Äôs role as the ‚Äúsocial infrastructure‚Äù underpinning all of it). After every trip, Zuckerberg posts earnest dispatches on his Facebook page, including images taken by the former Obama photographer who now accompanies Zuckerberg on his travels. A communications staffer also comes along to gather details, like the names and quotes that pepper the humanizing anecdotes that make up his posts. The whole thing makes for what one former Obama aide told BuzzFeed News is ‚Äúdefinitely an Obama-esque approach.‚Äù (Jon Lovett, a former speechwriter for both Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, went with a slightly different comparison onstage at South by Southwest last month: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why he sounds like a senator in his fourth term. Like, just talk, man! Don‚Äôt be so afraid.‚Äù) View this post on Facebook facebook.com It is indeed tempting to see Zuckerberg‚Äôs listening tour, manifesto, and newly folksy demeanor as an attempt to beta-test a presidential bid ‚Äî perhaps for 2020, the same year he turns 35. After all, Facebook‚Äôs platform has been known to launch a political career or two. Denials from Zuckerberg ‚Äî including telling BuzzFeed News in January that he had no plans to run for president ‚Äî have been laughed off. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand why he sounds like a senator in his fourth term. Like, just talk, man! Don‚Äôt be so afraid.‚Äù Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Facebook declined repeated requests to interview Zuckerberg on this topic (no surprise given the company‚Äôs zero-tolerance policy on acknowledging its own self-interest). But the CEO of a $400 billion company doesn‚Äôt schedule 30 action-packed trips in one year, with a small content production staff in tow, just to lend folks an ear. Facebook is a leviathan and, as its leader, Zuckerberg has plenty of reasons to benefit from a whistlestop tour without ever running for office. If you think of Zuckerberg as a startup CEO, positioning himself like a fourth-term senator doesn't make sense ‚Äî but it does if you think of him as the head of a 14-year-old nation-state called Facebook. At a time when Silicon Valley‚Äôs influence rivals Washington, DC's, Zuckerberg is using the framework of a political campaign (and its mix of the personal and the professional) to build a playbook for the modern-day CEO-statesman. ‚ÄúEvery single wealthy business person or billionaire has got to be watching Trump and thinking, 'I can do that and I have a lot of good ideas,'‚Äù said Swisher. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure [Zuckerberg] knows what he‚Äôs doing yet. He‚Äôs very very well meaning, at least compared to most people. He wants to find out if there‚Äôs some way to fix the damn thing.‚Äù In classic Facebook fashion, however, Zuckerberg has launched this political campaign without really taking a political position. (How else did he become the new poster CEO for civic engagement without ever disclosing who he voted for?) Where candidates want to win over citizens to push through policies and ideologies, CEOs need soft power to smooth the way for their ideas and products. The listening tour and manifesto are an opportunity for Zuckerberg to strengthen his relationship with his 1.8 billion constituents. ‚ÄúHe wants to build social capital and he knows he can‚Äôt do that if he has the nerdy-guy track record,‚Äù a former Facebook executive told BuzzFeed News. A guiding phrase inside Facebook is ‚Äúpreserving optionality‚Äù ‚Äî Stanford-speak for keeping your alternatives open. The same philosophy drove Facebook to place bets on every promising new technology platform from virtual reality to artificial intelligence: Zuckerberg has turned setting himself up to succeed into a science. And now, with the relatively recent formation of the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative ‚Äî the philanthropy-focused LLC to which he and his wife have pledged to donate 99% of their Facebook shares, worth an estimated $45 billion ‚Äî he is at the apex of his influence, with few signs of stopping. Zuckerberg has every reason to win your likes, and he‚Äôs built a remarkable apparatus to do it. View this post on Facebook Mark Zuckerberg / Facebook / Via facebook.com Zuckerberg‚Äôs sprint across the United States comes at a portentous moment for tech, and for Facebook. Katie Jacobs Stanton, a former Twitter executive who also worked as director of citizen participation under Obama, told BuzzFeed News that after years of measuring success on growth rates, monthly active users, and the efficiency of hiring fewer employees, the industry is looking around and wondering how it got here. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Silicon Valley growing up. After 10 to 15 years of thinking we were making the world a better place, [the events of the past year] have brought about some soul searching. We're in our adolescence stage ‚Äî optimistic, naive, and perhaps a bit awkward,‚Äù she said. At Facebook in particular, ‚Äúeveryone at that company is stinging from the post-election fallout,‚Äù said the former Obama aide. ‚ÄúNot just sensationalism or hyper-partisanship, but mainstreaming the alt-right and right-wing populist resurgence.‚Äù Right now, Zuckerberg needs public goodwill to protect the idea that his product is a tool for connectivity and not misinformation, mass surveillance, or censorship. Add to that Facebook‚Äôs stranglehold on the media and the $18 billion online advertising market, and suddenly the term ‚Äúantitrust regulation‚Äù sounds like more than just a quaint European custom. Lately, even the word ‚Äúplatform,‚Äù which once made it easy for tech companies to evade accountability, is starting to sound sinister. The New York Times recently argued that companies like Facebook, Google, and Uber are largely responsible for ‚Äúrehabilitating the concept‚Äù of a monopoly in their endless drive to dominate. At the same time, Silicon Valley‚Äôs pseudo-statesmen are coming to occupy an odd place in the cultural firmament as quasi-celebrities and sherpas to our uncertain future. ‚ÄúNever before have we had a time when we are so viscerally connected to company leaders,‚Äù Brooke Hammerling, a high-profile public relations executive and the founder of Brew PR, told BuzzFeed News. ‚ÄúMy parents were never like, ‚ÄòI love the founders of my refrigerator company!‚Äô‚Äù In this case, ‚Äúpeople who have never met Mark Zuckerberg call him Zuck. They spend their lives in these platforms and apps. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so important for the success of that company. He‚Äôs their public face.‚Äù Margit Wennmachers, a PR guru and partner at Andreessen Horowitz, which is also an investor in BuzzFeed, said that Zuckerberg has to deal with an added layer of complexity because he‚Äôs synonymous with Facebook. ‚ÄúYou end up being very associated with all the features and all the bugs,‚Äù she said. Thanks in part to Zuckerberg‚Äôs own creation, anyone with an online following can be a self-styled pundit. But unlike, say, a B-list actor tweeting about geopolitics, people actually want tech moguls to weigh in. Virtue signaling has become as much of a duty for a modern-day Silicon Valley CEO as writing a mission statement or releasing diversity numbers (even if the virtue is superficial and the diversity numbers are low). That personal connection with chief executives of consumer-facing companies comes with higher expectations. Perhaps to preempt social media scrutiny, tech CEOs and venture capitalists have been eager to volunteer themselves as socially conscious tribute over the past few months, treating Trump‚Äôs presidency as a second chance to make a good impression. Zuckerberg‚Äôs contemporaries are already copying his moves: ‚ÄúMany of us leaders have been inspired to speak up more recently,‚Äù Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky told Forbes India during a recent trip to the subcontinent. ‚ÄúWe preside over a huge community of people, and policies and the way people live together have an impact. When we design our community, we think like politicians legislating for their constituents.‚Äù Last month, John Zimmer, the CEO of Lyft, made the dynamic sound even more intimate, describing his ride-hailing software application as a ‚Äúbetter boyfriend‚Äù to consumers. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre woke,‚Äù said Zimmer, whose company is financed by the venture capital fund founded by top Trump adviser Peter Thiel (who also happens to be a Facebook board member). So before headlines accuse Zuckerberg of finally asphyxiating the media industry or dictating what your kid gets to learn in school (CZI‚Äôs personalized learning software is already being used by 20,000 students), why not bank some family-friendly pics of him posing with a shrimp boat captain or walking around the campus of a historically black college? Billionaires and tech titans ‚Äúwho successfully influence politics and policy have a public persona of being relatable and not seeming like they‚Äôre soulless,‚Äù the former Obama aide explained. It can only help Zuckerberg‚Äôs cause if he ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt just seem like some automaton when he‚Äôs trying to lobby Congress, but has a family and beliefs.‚Äù And as any modern influencer knows, there‚Äôs no better lobbyist for Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs personal brand than those closest to him: his brilliant, compassionate wife Priscilla, his adorable daughter Max, and their mop of a dog, Beast. Much like a lifestyle blogger, Zuckerberg uses his Palo Alto home as the backdrop for his posts as often as his instantly recognizable glass-walled conference room at Facebook‚Äôs headquarters, referred to internally as the Aquarium. ‚ÄúPeople trust people more when they get a sense of them as human beings,‚Äù said Reid Hoffman, the founder of LinkedIn and a longtime friend and mentor of Zuckerberg‚Äôs. It‚Äôs a new twist on the old saying: If the CEO is not ‚Äã(overtly) ‚Äãselling the product, he is the product. Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Even his philanthropist buddy Bill Gates is participating in the performative fun. Zuckerberg recently posted a Saturday Night Live‚Äìstyle promo of himself and Gates in which Zuck aims to build up hype for his upcoming Harvard commencement speech. (‚ÄúThey know we didn‚Äôt actually graduate, right?‚Äù Zuckerberg quips, billionaire to billionaire, to lighten the mood.) When this strategy is at its best, Zuckerberg conflates the personal and the professional seamlessly. It‚Äôs a new twist on the old saying: If the CEO is not ‚Äã(overtly) ‚Äãselling the product, he is the product. At Facebook‚Äôs F8 developer conference in April 2016, Zuckerberg used his own life as a way to explain the importance of 360-degree video. ‚ÄúWhen I was a baby and I took my first steps, my parents wrote the date in a baby book,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd when my daughter Max takes her first steps hopefully later this year, I want to capture the whole scene with a 360 video.‚Äù Eight months later, in December, Zuckerberg posted a 360 video that he had teased of Max walking. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre connected to him on an emotional level,‚Äù said Hammerling of the video, adding of course that it ‚Äúshowcased the technology in such a beautiful way.‚Äù View this post on Facebook Facebook: video.php It may be hard to remember this now, but Zuckerberg used to be a pretty private guy. The world didn‚Äôt know what his living room looked like, how many pull-ups he could do, or even what brand of gray T-shirt he wore. (The smart money‚Äôs on this $300 number from Italy.) When Hoffman first met Zuckerberg more than a decade ago, the young startup founder was uncertain about putting himself out there. Zuckerberg wondered, ‚ÄúHow much of my personal life should I share? Is it a useful thing for the kind of things I‚Äôm trying to do in the world?‚Äù Hoffman told BuzzFeed News. The chief executive was so camera-shy that one candid photo of the Zuckerberg clan ‚Äî taken by his sister Randi, who didn‚Äôt understand Facebook‚Äôs privacy settings ‚Äî prompted a ripple of schadenfreude across the blogosphere in 2012 when it was shared publicly. Back then, Hoffman recalled, critics thought Zuckerberg was an ‚Äúon-the-spectrum tech genius trying to kind of rule the world.‚Äù It didn‚Äôt help that for several months in 2010, Jesse Eisenberg‚Äôs sullen mug was staring into the middle distance on movie posters across America to hype Aaron Sorkin‚Äôs The Social Network, the unauthorized biopic that introduced Zuckerberg to much of the world as a prickly lout. And early attempts to schedule positive PR to offset public embarrassments didn‚Äôt play out well ‚Äî like Zuckerberg‚Äôs exhaustively orchestrated appearance on Oprah to announce a $100 million donation to the Newark schools, which not-so-coincidentally aired a week before the movie‚Äôs premiere. But around the time that Zuckerberg and Chan were expecting their first child, things began to change. Many sources pointed to his announcement about their first daughter Max as a turning point in their impression of Zuckerberg. In the post, Zuckerberg discussed the trouble they had conceiving, a private struggle many couples are too ashamed to discuss publicly. (The post got more than 1.7 million likes and was shared more than 50,000 times.) According to a source familiar with Facebook‚Äôs strategy, Zuckerberg‚Äôs more concerted embrace of social media came after that, in late 2015. When it began, the company had a few priorities in mind: to be perceived as a world-class tech company and not just a social media app, to demonstrate that Facebook is concerned about people, and to make Zuckerberg more likable. That timeline lines up with a report in The Information that Facebook began closely tracking a metric called ‚ÄúCares About Users,‚Äù or CAU (pronounced ‚Äúcow‚Äù inside the company) in the winter of 2014. Two other carefully monitored metrics look at whether Facebook seems innovative and whether Facebook seems like a force for good. But the best example of this shift toward social media psy-ops might be a series of slick videos about Jarvis, the digital butler that Zuckerberg coded from scratch for his 2016 personal challenge. The mini movie trailers touch on all those notes (likable, caring, innovative, good for humanity), but in a more subtle way than those overly cheery greetings that Facebook started serving at the top of your feed. In the spots, Jarvis, voiced by Morgan Freeman, helps Zuckerberg make toast, let his parents in the front door, and teach his daughter Mandarin. The videos are selling a sentiment: Artificial intelligence is useful, personal, and safe to use at home. Mark Zuckerberg is an approachable, nerdy family man and kooky inventor. When you think of AI, think of Facebook. Shortly after the ad‚Äôs debut, Facebook posted a job listing for a video producer whose duties included helping Facebook‚Äôs CEO. And it‚Äôs not incidental that many of the people contacted by BuzzFeed News seemed allergic to acknowledging that Zuckerberg‚Äôs transformation may have required help (or in some cases even that it took place). They will tell you, unprompted, that Mark is an incredible learner and an unparalleled listener. But ask what he learned from or who he listened to and they‚Äôll tell you you‚Äôre missing the point. The point, you see, is that he learns and listens. People close to Zuckerberg are so deeply invested in Zuckerberg‚Äôs appearance of authenticity that you can practically hear them erasing themselves from the picture. View this post on Facebook Facebook: video.php Which brings us to the listening tour and the manifesto. In both cases, Facebook seems to be capitalizing on something that Zuckerberg began organically. The manifesto started with the CEO himself, writing it on nights and weekends. (No comms team is going to ask for a 6,000-word treatise.) Then Facebook, a company obsessed with scale and infrastructure, seems to have grafted a promotional strategy on top of it. Zuckerberg has always argued that a for-profit company is the best way to do good in the world. And throughout both these efforts, the solution Zuckerberg suggests is often more Facebook, further centralizing his power. In fact, the listening tour is looking less like a presidential gambit and more like a focus group. Zuckerberg is not talking to military spouses about the defense budget or veterans affairs. He‚Äôs not talking to Mother Emanuel church congregants about domestic terrorists and hate crimes. He‚Äôs talking to them about the importance of community and, by extension, about Facebook. After lunch with military spouses in Fort Bragg, North Carolina, he noted that they use ‚Äúa combination of Facebook, Messenger, WhatsApp, and Skype‚Äù to stay connected with deployed family members. (Zuckerberg‚Äôs corporation owns three of the four technologies he named.) Zuckerberg's listening tour is less a presidential gambit than a focus group with Facebook users. Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share There are easier ways to appear woke than traveling across the country to talk about Facebook‚Äôs weak spots. By the same token, the 6,000-word manifesto shows Zuckerberg beginning to grapple with Facebook‚Äôs responsibility. But the letter was also widely interpreted as a public stand against nativism. (The New York Times said it ‚Äúcomes close to a political statement.") When boiled down, however, it read more like a product road map. Each section starts at 20,000 feet, but dwindles down to an upcoming Facebook feature ‚Äî a feature that, if launched, will now get swept up into Zuckerberg‚Äôs ‚Äúglobalization‚Äù crusade, instead of an aging platform‚Äôs attempt to drive user engagement. Perhaps purposefully, Zuckerberg overshot his mark: Facebook users were asking him to fix fake news, and he responded with plans to fix global society. The social network‚Äôs top brass has used this antiseptic approach before, during the campaign around Lean In, the self-help book for working women written by Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg, who is fending off her own rumors about running for president. Both Lean In and the listening tour appear to engage with a controversial issue, while glossing over Facebook‚Äôs role (in the lack of diversity in tech and the lack of diversity of news information, respectively). Sandberg supported feminism the way Zuckerberg supports globalization: from so high in the clouds you can barely see if anything‚Äôs changing on the ground. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre very careful, very studious, they don‚Äôt wanna rock the boat, like when they met with conservatives,‚Äù Swisher said. ‚ÄúSome people might say, ‚ÄòOh, just tell them to shut up!‚Äô But they couldn‚Äôt do that when, you know, all of them are Democrats and all of them are very liberal.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt the same time, you‚Äôre this rich and this famous, you might want to stand for something.‚Äù Maciej Ceg≈Çowski, a tech CEO and critic who has been hosting Tech Solidarity meetups with industry employees around the country, said this approach is disingenuous considering all the data Facebook is sitting on, like information about micro-targeted campaigns that were run during the election to suppress African-American voters. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much duplicity in how he writes about connecting the world,‚Äù said Ceg≈Çowski. ‚ÄúHe has a really rich trove of data on people and he‚Äôs still arguing from general principles about what is community.‚Äù Facebook vice president Elliot Schrage, who, along with Sandberg, is one of Zuckerberg‚Äôs advisers, laid out the strategy behind this in emails about the Oprah appearance that were obtained through public record requests. ‚ÄúEmploy language that resonates well with a mass audience, without alienating potential adversaries,‚Äù he wrote in 2010. ‚ÄúOur goal is to better explain objectives and avoid hot-button words if we can.‚Äù When you‚Äôre trying to appease American conservatives and Chinese officials at the same time, it‚Äôs safer to throw out anodyne terms. ‚ÄúAdvancing human potential‚Äù is less likely to raise hackles than ‚Äúadvancing charter schools,‚Äù a cause that Zuckerberg has supported in the past, just as ‚Äúglobalization‚Äù is safer than ‚Äúdemocracy‚Äù or ‚Äúfree trade‚Äù and ‚Äúsensationalism‚Äù has more gravitas than ‚Äúfake news.‚Äù The CEO of Facebook doesn‚Äôt need to run for office to benefit from the public perception that he‚Äôs a thoughtful, politically engaged innovator building the scaffolding for the future of the global community. Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Pin Share On email Share On email Share On link Share On link Share This Link Bloomberg / Getty Images Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Share On pinterest Pin President Barack Obama and Mark Zuckerberg during the 2016 Global Entrepreneurship Summit at Stanford University, June 24, 2016. If anything, Zuckerberg‚Äôs political agenda has been hiding in plain sight. He wants to win over the world to help his philanthropic interests. In an email to Hillary Clinton‚Äôs campaign chairman John Podesta that was later published by WikiLeaks, Sandberg ‚Äî who was expected to serve as Hillary Clinton‚Äôs treasury secretary if the election went a different way ‚Äî implored Podesta to advise Zuckerberg on the best way to build ‚Äúeffective political operations‚Äù in order to advance public policy goals in areas like ‚Äúimmigration, education or basic scientific research.‚Äù Zuckerberg‚Äôs first foray into politics was an immigration advocacy super PAC called FWD.us, which he mentioned in a recent Facebook post about Trump‚Äôs immigration order; CZI‚Äôs top priorities are changing policy in education and science. In January, the initiative announced that it hired former Obama campaign manager David Plouffe as ‚Äúpolitical muscle‚Äù for its advocacy goals. (Ken Mehlman, who managed George W. Bush‚Äôs re-election campaign, will sit on CZI‚Äôs advisory board.) In an interview with the New York Times, Zuckerberg argued that bipartisan political operatives were necessary for CZI to do its good work: ‚ÄúYou can make change, but in order for it to be sustainable, you need to build a movement to support it.‚Äù A job application for CZI‚Äôs director of advocacy says candidates must be as comfortable in a room full of engineers as they are ‚Äúin the basement of a church rallying people to organize on behalf of criminal justice reform." Zuckerberg is far from the first capitalist to switch gears from showing no mercy in the public markets to launching a massive foundation. ‚ÄúSome people choose to focus on building their business before turning to philanthropy in a big way,‚Äù Microsoft founder Bill Gates wrote in an email to BuzzFeed News. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs exciting and inspiring to see younger people like Mark and Priscilla realize that they can do both ‚Äî they can make an incredible impact on the world through philanthropy and Mark can continue to build and lead Facebook to new heights.‚Äù That desire to ‚Äúdo both‚Äù helps explain why Zuckerberg might need the brownie points. Uber‚Äôs downward spiral over the past few months is ample evidence of how much a company‚Äôs bottom line can rest on the public‚Äôs impression of its CEO. Likability is an asset when it comes to backlash from Facebook‚Äôs disillusioned workforce, populist backlash against Silicon Valley, even faith in the free market itself. (After the launch of CZI, The New Yorker wrote that charitable giving on this scale makes the inequalities of modern capitalism ‚Äúseem somewhat more defensible.‚Äù Tech columnist David Pogue shared a similar sentiment, except a decade earlier, declaring that he could no longer consider the founder of Microsoft a ruthless monopolist after he donated 95% of his fortune: ‚ÄúMr. Gates‚Äôs entire life arc suddenly looks like a 35-year game of Robin Hood.‚Äù In interviews with BuzzFeed News, Zuckerberg‚Äôs mentors ‚Äî including Hoffman, SV Angel founder Ron Conway, and early Facebook employee Matt Cohler, who is now a partner at Benchmark Capital ‚Äî all argued that Zuckerberg‚Äôs recent likability blitz is genuine, part of a continuous evolution brought on by increased maturity, acceptance of responsibility, and becoming a dad. As Hoffman ‚Äî who recently announced a $20 million donation to CZI‚Äôs Biohub ‚Äî said, if in 2010 Zuckerberg‚Äôs public perception was as a hoodie-wearing creep with poor social skills, now there‚Äôs a realization that ‚Äúin addition to a super smart, super capable guy, he is also is a loving father, he has kind of a personal voice, he has emotional vibrancy.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo I think it‚Äôs calculated? Absolutely, but that doesn‚Äôt mean calculated in a bad way.‚Äù Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share Share On facebook Share On facebook Share Share On twitter Share On twitter Share ‚ÄúDo I think it‚Äôs calculated?‚Äù Hammerling asked. ‚ÄúAbsolutely, but that doesn‚Äôt mean calculated in a bad way. He‚Äôs testing his comfort level.‚Äù Hoffman stressed that the newfound personal transparency isn‚Äôt a PR ploy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs substantive. It‚Äôs not like marketing, brand image, ‚ÄòOh, I‚Äôm gonna do the cute dog pictures because everybody likes cute dog pictures and letters to children.‚Äô‚Äù In his view, Zuckerberg is ‚Äúworking aggressively to have a bunch of power in order to move the world the right way‚Äù and is earnestly committed to his mission. It may look like he‚Äôs power hungry, but Zuckerberg simply trusts himself, and with good reason. Historically, a former executive said, Zuckerberg's "long-term decision-making worked out better than instincts of other people who may have influenced him, like Wall Street.‚Äù When Facebook first launched, it had a tagline across the bottom of the page that said ‚Äúa Mark Zuckerberg production‚Äù; perhaps that‚Äôs still the case. The same former Facebook executive described Zuckerberg as a genuinely curious person who wants to understand the world. Like many other Americans, elites or otherwise, Zuckerberg is trying to get out of his filter bubble. ‚ÄúPeople can make fun of him going around the country and visiting diners, but they‚Äôre all sitting in their little homes trying to one up each other,‚Äù said Swisher, ‚ÄúAt least someone is trying, even if it seems like French King visiting the countryside.‚Äù Nitasha Tiku is a senior writer for BuzzFeed News and is based in San Francisco. Contact Nitasha Tiku at nitasha.tiku@buzzfeed.com. Got a confidential tip? Submit it here. Her body was found half a mile away from her home. This week,¬†CNN reports that police have arrested the man they believe¬†killed her. Screenshot/CBS Boston On Saturday, Worcester County District Attorney Joseph Early Jr. announced in a press conference: ‚ÄúWe got him. We're very confident that we got Vanessa Marcotte's killer.‚Äù Loading Facebook Video... CBS¬†Boston reports that Angelo Colon-Ortiz, 31, was arrested on Saturday¬†morning for assault and battery with intent to rape. Early anticipates that a murder charge will be added this week. On August 7, 2016, police officers were called when family members were unable to find Marcotte. Her body¬†was located¬†on the side of a two-lane road by a Massachusetts State Police K9 unit at 8:30 p.m. She was naked and had burns on her head, hands, and feet. Police believe Marcotte¬†put up a fight before she died. Experts at the Massachusetts crime lab were able to remove DNA from her hands. After Marcotte was found, the¬†Washington Post¬†reports, police officers recorded¬†more than 1,300 tips from the public. Several witnesses reported seeing a dark SUV parked on the side of the road at the time of the incident. Police also looking for dark SUV seen in the area on the day Vanessa Marcotte was killed https://t.co/pewAXru94F pic.twitter.com/m0uM9cwp8K‚Äî The Boston Globe (@BostonGlobe) February 23, 2017 Police officers started¬†searching¬†for a man with scratches on his arms and face, driving a dark-colored SUV. In February, Boston Globe reports, the DNA evidence from her hands returned more details about the suspect. They knew they were looking for a man with Hispanic or Latino features. #VanessaMarcotte person of interest described as Hispanic or Latino man w/athletic build, short hair/shaved head, about 30 years old #wcvb‚Äî Erika Tarantal (@ErikaWCVB) February 23, 2017 Investigators¬†got a lucky break¬†when Trooper Robert Parr¬†spotted a man who matched¬†the description of the suspect driving a dark SUV. Parr¬†wrote down the license plate on his hand and later tracked down his address. When the police went to investigate the suspect, they discovered¬†that Colon-Ortiz speaks limited English. They had to¬†use an interpreter to question him. During the press conference, Early said the department cannot comment on the status of his citizenship at this time. @JadedByPolitics 31-year-old Angelo Colon-Ortiz "speaks some English," according to DA. Used interpreter during questioning.‚Äî Stephe96 (@Stephe96) April 15, 2017 Upon request, Colon-Ortiz¬†provided a buccal¬†swab to police. It matched the DNA sample that had been scraped from Marcotte's hands. Early said as soon as the DNA was a confirmed match, they arrested Colon-Ortiz: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs through her determined fight and her efforts that we obtained the DNA of her killer.‚Äù He also added that Marcotte's family and friends have been helpful throughout¬†the investigation. They were contacted early in the morning on Saturday about the arrest. Later that evening, they released a¬†statement: ‚ÄúAfter eight long months, we're able to take the first step toward justice for Vanessa. She was a beautiful, intelligent, and generous young woman whose passion for giving back to the community will always be remembered. As we move forward, her spirit will live on through The Vanessa T. Marcotte Foundation that strives to empower women to live boldly and fearlessly.‚Äù ICYMI: Best friend to run @bostonmarathon in memory of Princeton jogger, Vanessa Marcotte.Her very inspiring story. https://t.co/j6RyRPUwHe‚Äî Katelyn Flint (@KFlintNBCBoston) April 12, 2017 Authorities¬†will continue their investigation this week. Early¬†said they never once gave up on their search to find¬†Marcotte's killer. Colon-Ortiz is currently being held on a $10 million bail and he's scheduled to appear in court on Tuesday. ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† View Comments(0 comments) Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via email ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Join/LoginSearchDiscuss About usCareersAdvertiseContactPrivacy¬©Copyright 2017 all rights reserved
Now Boarding - By Les Shu ¬† Digital Trends Home > Mobile > Need to get away? 5 ways to book a much-needed‚Ä¶ Need to get away? 5 ways to book a much-needed, impromptu vacay By Les Shu ‚Äî April 16, 2017 1:00 PM Subscribe Share Don't Fall Behind Stay current with a recap of today's Tech News from Digital¬†Trends Get today's popular Digital¬†Trends articles in your inbox: Summer is approaching, and that means we have wanderlust in our minds. Many will have already planned in advanced, but if you‚Äôre like this writer, you‚Äôll leave it to the last minute. Congratulations, you are a ‚Äúspontaneous traveler,‚Äù a term that‚Äôs being kicked around in the travel industry to describe a trend in post-Boomer generations. This shift mirrors how we travel plan today. We no longer drive to the travel agency, but pull up a travel site to book our flights and hotels. But even that‚Äôs becoming old school: A lot more of us are now using apps on our phones. And with a desire for on-demand pricing and booking, there are plenty of travel apps that do just that. But what if you are looking for inspiration? While most apps are good at handle the basic transactions, few can offer insights or recommendations. If you‚Äôre looking for some help in planning a last-minute getaway, these six apps are our current favorites. Google Flights Google Flights is useful for looking up real-time airfare and price fluctuations, but if you‚Äôre looking for inspiration, the website (there‚Äôs no app) has a handy discovery tool. Punch in some dates or search by month, length of trip, places, and interests. You can leave it vague if you want a wide selection of suggestions, or narrow down to a specific weekend or location. The website shows a visual list of recommended cities, along with estimated pricing for flights (based on your point of departure) and hotels, as well as interests (we‚Äôre not sure we would count ‚Äúfog‚Äù as our must-see attraction in San Francisco, but to each his own). If you have a strict budget, use the ‚ÄúExplore map‚Äù view to adjust the search parameters to include a price cap. Then, pan through the map to see what surprising locations pop up. Hit the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Feeling Lucky‚Äù button if you really want to be spontaneous. Hopper We‚Äôve sung many praises¬†for Hopper, the flight search app that uses artificial intelligence and big data to make fare predictions. It tells you the best times to book, and you can have Hopper keep watch for better prices. Hopper‚Äôs results can help you determine whether you should make that last-minute getaway or save it for another time. A new feature we like is Fair Bear. Essentially, it‚Äôs an overview of the fine print associated with an airfare that many travelers may not pay attention to. While a fare may be the cheapest, it could come with a lot of restrictions. As airlines continue to introduce confusing pricing tiers and new fees, Fair Bear gives a quick nutshell of what you‚Äôre getting into, and whether the price is worth it. HotelTonight With the rise in what‚Äôs being termed ‚Äúspontaneous travel,‚Äù many hotel booking services are now catering to last-minute travelers. The one app that‚Äôs the most popular is HotelTonight, which focuses solely on this type of travel. HotelTonight says it offers heavily discounted rates, and we found this to be accurate. In one search, a HotelTonight rate for one hotel was $100 (or more) cheaper than other booking sites, include the hotel‚Äôs. The only downside we notice is that hotels tend to be on the pricier side, but the positive is that they are all highly rated properties, so you don‚Äôt have to scroll through hundreds of listings. Airbnb While it‚Äôs better known as the app for short-term vacation rentals, Airbnb also offers a service called Experiences. As the name suggests, these are events hosted by in-the-know locals that focus on interests in the area, like sake tasting in Tokyo, home cooking in Bangkok, trail exploration in Portland, Oregon. If you‚Äôre looking to include some authentic experiences ‚Äì whether it‚Äôs the arts, food, nature, etc. ‚Äì in your trip, this is a nicer alternative to packaged tours. Of course, you can still use the app to book last-minute lodging. Google Trips Not to be confused with Google Flights, Google Trips is an iOS and Android app for planning and managing itineraries. It‚Äôs great for those who already have a flight reserved (if you use Gmail for bookings, it can search for trips ‚Äì past and future ‚Äì and automatically add them to the list), but haven‚Äôt done any research on things to do and see, places to eat, important info to know, how to get around, etc. ‚Äì city guides essentially. Besides suggestions, Google Trips can even plan entire itineraries for select destinations, which is perfect for the lazy, last minute non-planner.

Microsoft‚Äôs Next Surface Book Will Be Education Focused That Runs Windows 10 Cloud: Poised To Take On Google‚Äôs ChromeBook N. GutierrezApr 16, 2017 02:19 AM EDT Facebook Linkedin Twitter Google+ Print Email (Photo : Andrew Burton/Getty Images) Microsoft's rumored new Surface device is reported to run on Windows 10 Cloud and would sport an ARM-processor. Microsoft was seen to be out powered by Google in terms of education laptop systems in the previous years. Yet, this time the company aims to create a new Microsoft Surface Book that would target education along with the rumored integration of Windows 10 Cloud. According to Digital Trends, Microsoft is planning to release an education focused Microsoft¬† Surface Book, especially for students. As people know Chromebook takes the lead in the category, but Microsoft was reported to take on the prime with full force and releases its rumored Windows 10 Cloud. Like Us on Facebook Related Stories Huawei MateBooks Leaked: Three 2-in-1 Devices Poised To Compete With ... Chromebook Codenamed ‚ÄòKahlee‚Äô Powered With AMD CPU May Be Coming Soon Apple Redefines Mac Pro With New Modular Models Due To Consumers Negative ... Microsoft Vs. Apple Tablets: Surface Pro 4 Tops iPad Pro In J.D. Powers ... Samsung Galaxy S8 vs. Apple iPhone 7 Plus: Is it Worth To Switch ... Windows 10 Cloud was then explained to be a system that would only allow Universal Windows Platform apps, Win32 programs, and other apps to be downloaded from the Windows store. Hence, the expected new Microsoft Surface Book was considered by some to be the perfect alternative for Chrome OS. Liliputing¬†mentioned that as Google Chromebooks were said to be favored by students due to its security patches, the new Microsoft Surface Book which would be Cloud-based could be a formidable competitor as well. The Windows 10 Cloud system would indeed aid administrators‚Äô total control over their student‚Äôs laptops as reported. IDC PC sales tracker, Jay Chou also added that ‚ÄúThe saving grace for Microsoft right now is that Chromebooks are having trouble at anything outside English-speaking markets right now.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey have good traction in the U.S. and Canada, and nothing much more beyond that,‚Äù further adding another advantage of a possible new Microsoft Surface Book over Chromebooks. Some rumors were leaked about the new Microsoft Surface Book education-focused device as well. The device was speculated to run an ARM-based processor that would lessen the cost and provide a long lasting battery. But some expect it to sports Intel‚Äôs Kaby Lake chips. Another rumor is that the device will not carry the Surface name but a ‚ÄòCloudbook‚Äô series instead similar to the Surface, Nexus, and Pixel series. Meanwhile, other rumors regarding Microsoft‚Äôs May 2 event aside from the new Microsoft Surface Book was shared by PC World.¬†It was mentioned that a Surface Pro running on Intel Kaby Lake chipset is expected by tech enthusiasts. Windows 10 replacing Windows mobile was also rumored to become possible as well. Lastly, it was speculated that Microsoft might be unveiling its Cortana-powered devices along with improved features that failed during the Windows 10 Creators Update. Microsoft‚Äôs May 2 #MicrosoftEDU event in New York City was speculated to be the launch date for the new Microsoft Surface Book Windows 10 Cloud education based device. Nonetheless, any details or hints about the device weren't given by the Washington-based company. Boulder menu News News Announcements Breaking News Funding Channels Channels 3D Printing Cloud Storage Dev & Design Ecommerce Ecosystems Gadgets Marketing Mobile Productivity Reports & Rankings Sharing Economy Wearables Cities Cities Albuquerque Atlanta Austin Baltimore Boise Boston Charleston Chicago Dallas DC Denver Kansas City Las Vegas Los Angeles Miami New York City Pittsburgh Portland ME San Diego San Francisco Seattle Events Events SXSW 2017 Events Startup of the Year Tech.Co Events Celebrate 2016 Industry Events Ecosystem Ecosystem Accelerator Coworking spaces Hackathon Incubator Jobs Resources Resources Books Finance Healthy Entrepreneur Productivity Tips & How To‚Äôs News Announcements Breaking News Funding Channels 3D Printing Cloud Storage Dev & Design Ecommerce Ecosystems Gadgets Marketing Mobile Productivity Reports & Rankings Sharing Economy Wearables Cities Albuquerque Atlanta Austin Baltimore Boise Boston Charleston Chicago Dallas DC Denver Kansas City Las Vegas Los Angeles Miami New York City Pittsburgh Portland ME San Diego San Francisco Seattle Events SXSW 2017 Events Startup of the Year Tech.Co Events Celebrate 2016 Industry Events Ecosystem Accelerator Coworking spaces Hackathon Incubator Jobs Resources Books Finance Healthy Entrepreneur Productivity Tips & How To‚Äôs jobs How Microsoft, Uber, Twitter, and Google Came to Boulder Boulder Ecosystems David Cohen @davidcohen April 15, 2017 2:30 pm 0 Shares A thriving startup community provides a boost to the greater community in a lot of different ways. It encourages innovation and investment, attracts¬†creative people, and generates a certain energy‚Äì making the entire city a more desirable place to live. Additionally, when local startups are acquired by big companies, and those companies hire more people in the area, the result is more jobs, which boosts the local economy in a lot of new ways. A great example of how big companies get here is Sketchup, a startup that my partner Mark Solon invested in back when it was a tiny company. Google acquired Sketchup in 2006, and we‚Äôve had the footprint of Google‚Äôs presence in Boulder ever since then. Bolstered by the addition of around 1,500 jobs in Boulder, over the years that acquisition has significantly contributed to Boulder‚Äôs growth and housing boom. Similarly, in 2011 Federated Media purchased Lijit (now Sovrn), leading to an increase in hiring at the Boulder office. And in 2014, Boulder startup Gnip was acquired by Twitter, leading to their large office here. By the way, even as I write this,¬†Twitter has ten job openings in Boulder right now. Microsoft brought an office to Boulder when it bought the startup Vexcel. Later, Uber opened up a Boulder office when it acquired some of the Bing assets and Microsoft continued to operate here. There are plenty of other examples in Boulder alone. By my count, about 2,000 high paying, high tech, ‚Äúbig company‚Äù jobs in Boulder can be traced back to startups from the last decade. Not to mention the many thousands more jobs that are enabled by the current generation of startups today. This is how an active startup community impacts the broader community, well beyond¬†just the startup community itself. It impacts all aspects of the area, including real estate, retail and housing in major ways. Next time you find yourself wondering if startups really matter to a community, take a look at Boulder and ask yourself why Google and Twitter employ so many people here. Startups are responsible for most net new jobs in America.¬†As big companies continue to cut back, we can continue to look to startups to create our future. The purpose of Techstars‚Äô Worldwide Entrepreneur Network is to help entrepreneurs succeed. Check out the impact of the Techstars‚Äô network over the past 10 years. This post originally appeared on David Cohen‚Äôs own blog at¬†davidgcohen.com Photo: Flickr /¬†Pedro Szekely This article is courtesy of¬†Techstars, the best global ecosystem for entrepreneurs to bring new technologies to market. From inspiration to IPO, Techstars empowers the world‚Äôs most promising entrepreneurs throughout their lifelong journey by providing a global ecosystem made up of tens of thousands of community leaders, founders, mentors, investors, and corporate partners. People folders in Google Photos are disappearing for some, Google is on the case Ryne Hager Follow View All Posts 2017/04/16 3:11pm PDTApr 16, 2017 36 Plus 1 on G+ 73 Share on Facebook 55 Share on Twitter Total Shares164 Applications Bug Watch Google News This holiday weekend might result in some slightly disorganized photos. The automatically created "People" folders in Google Photos are disappearing for some people. At least now you'll have some kind of excuse not to have to show your great-aunt pictures of your kids egg-hunting. It looks like the trouble cropped up sometime in the last few days. Google has already let people that reported the problem on their forum know that it is aware of the issue and is looking for a fix. To see if you've been affected hop on Google Photos and check your "People" album. If you see expected faces missing you're either one of the unlucky ones, or your parents' date at the school dance back in 1955 isn't going too well. In the meantime, if you discover that you are among those experiencing the problem, now you know Google is hot on the case. Should they provide an update on the forums relating to the trouble then we'll be sure to let you know. Economy Federal Reserve Capitol Report Economic Report Columns Darrell Delamaide Irwin Kellner Rex Nutting Tools Economic Calendar Real Estate Location Scouts realtor.com My MarketWatch Watchlist Alerts Games Log In Home General National news The New York Post Get email alerts The New York Post Suspected killer of NYC Google exec arrested after DNA match By David K. Li Published: Apr 16, 2017 6:04 p.m. ET Share Vanessa Marcotte was killed jogging in Massachusetts last summer Getty Images/iStockphoto Police found the body of Vanessa Marcotte last August in Princeton, Mass. By DavidK. Li A suspect was arrested in the slaying of a Google executive from New York ‚Äì who played a key role in the capture of her own killer, Massachusetts officials said Saturday. Angelo Colon Ortiz, a 31-year-old Worcester resident, was arrested on Friday night after his DNA matched that found on victim Vanessa Marcotte‚Äôs hands, officials said. ‚ÄúGood afternoon, we got him,‚Äù Worcester District Attorney Joseph Early Jr. told reporters to the cheers of bystanders. After thanking a laundry list of law enforcement agencies, Early singled out the victim and how she played the key role in Ortiz‚Äôs arrest. ‚ÄúThere is also one other person I‚Äôd like to thank in this case, that would be Vanessa Marcotte,‚Äù Early said. ‚ÄúIt was through her determined fight and her efforts that we obtained the DNA of her killer.‚Äù Marcotte was visiting her mom in Princeton, Mass., when she went out for a jog the afternoon of Aug. 7. Her body was found hours later in nearby woods. The 27-year-old Google accounts manager‚Äôs slaying followed the Aug. 2 murder of Queens resident Karina Vetrano. Vetrano, 30, was also out jogging when she vanished, though no solid connections were ever made between the two murders, 200 miles apart. Massachusetts authorities announced on Feb. 23 they had recovered DNA of the suspect in Marcotte‚Äôs killing ‚Äî and that it didn‚Äôt match Chanel Lewis, the Brooklyn man arrested in Vetrano‚Äôs killing. Early eyewitnesses accounts noted a dark SUV driven by a Hispanic male near Marcotte‚Äôs murder scene. A state trooper recently spotted an SUV matching that description and the lawman ‚Äì without a piece of paper in reach ‚Äì wrote the license plate number on his hand, according to Early. Detectives eventually found Ortiz, who gave up a cheek swab of his DNA which led to his arrest, the DA said. Ortiz has been charged with aggravated assault and aggravated assault with intent to commit rape. His first court appearance is set for Tuesday. This report originally appeared on NYPost.com. Tech Entertainment Business Deals Science Politics About Apps & Software Image Source: Google Google Photos will now stabilize your shaky smartphone videos Jacob Siegal @JacobSiegal April 16th, 2017 at 3:00 PM Share Tweet One of Google‚Äôs most underrated smartphone apps just quietly got even better this week. According to Android Police, the latest version of the Google Photos app will allow users to stabilize videos with the press of a button. All you need to do to stabilize your videos is download the latest version of the app on your Android device, tap on the pen icon to edit it and look for the ‚ÄúStabilize‚Äù button at the bottom left. Don't Miss: Galaxy S8 sales are already explosive As Android Police notes, video stabilization has been in the works for Google Photos for quite some time. Google¬†began working to bring the feature to the app last August, and although it took nearly a year for the company to finalize it, it will be a welcome addition for anyone who uses the app and frequently takes videos. Once you hit the ‚ÄúStabilize‚Äù button, you will have to wait for the video to stabilize, which could be nearly instantaneous for a short clip or take well over a minute for a longer clip. The effects aren‚Äôt quite as drastic as some of the hardware stabilization that exists in modern smartphones, but it definitely makes a difference. In fact, you can see for yourself how much of a difference it makes in this comparison video: You can download the latest version of Google Photos from Google Play right now. Economy Federal Reserve Capitol Report Economic Report Columns Darrell Delamaide Irwin Kellner Rex Nutting Tools Economic Calendar Real Estate Location Scouts realtor.com My MarketWatch Watchlist Alerts Games Log In Home General National news The New York Post Get email alerts The New York Post Suspected killer of NYC Google exec arrested after DNA match By David K. Li Published: Apr 16, 2017 6:04 p.m. ET Share Vanessa Marcotte was killed jogging in Massachusetts last summer Getty Images/iStockphoto Police found the body of Vanessa Marcotte last August in Princeton, Mass. By DavidK. Li A suspect was arrested in the slaying of a Google executive from New York ‚Äì who played a key role in the capture of her own killer, Massachusetts officials said Saturday. Angelo Colon Ortiz, a 31-year-old Worcester resident, was arrested on Friday night after his DNA matched that found on victim Vanessa Marcotte‚Äôs hands, officials said. ‚ÄúGood afternoon, we got him,‚Äù Worcester District Attorney Joseph Early Jr. told reporters to the cheers of bystanders. After thanking a laundry list of law enforcement agencies, Early singled out the victim and how she played the key role in Ortiz‚Äôs arrest. ‚ÄúThere is also one other person I‚Äôd like to thank in this case, that would be Vanessa Marcotte,‚Äù Early said. ‚ÄúIt was through her determined fight and her efforts that we obtained the DNA of her killer.‚Äù Marcotte was visiting her mom in Princeton, Mass., when she went out for a jog the afternoon of Aug. 7. Her body was found hours later in nearby woods. The 27-year-old Google accounts manager‚Äôs slaying followed the Aug. 2 murder of Queens resident Karina Vetrano. Vetrano, 30, was also out jogging when she vanished, though no solid connections were ever made between the two murders, 200 miles apart. Massachusetts authorities announced on Feb. 23 they had recovered DNA of the suspect in Marcotte‚Äôs killing ‚Äî and that it didn‚Äôt match Chanel Lewis, the Brooklyn man arrested in Vetrano‚Äôs killing. Early eyewitnesses accounts noted a dark SUV driven by a Hispanic male near Marcotte‚Äôs murder scene. A state trooper recently spotted an SUV matching that description and the lawman ‚Äì without a piece of paper in reach ‚Äì wrote the license plate number on his hand, according to Early. Detectives eventually found Ortiz, who gave up a cheek swab of his DNA which led to his arrest, the DA said. Ortiz has been charged with aggravated assault and aggravated assault with intent to commit rape. His first court appearance is set for Tuesday. This report originally appeared on NYPost.com. NASAOceanWorlds NESClassicEdition Menu Subscribe Home/ Reviews/ Consumer Electronics/ Cars/ Connected Car Data Is the New Oil Connected Car Data Is the New Oil By Doug Newcomb April 14, 2017 07:32pm EST 10 Comments In three years, automakers could make more money from connected vehicle data than car sales. Last November, Intel CEO Brian Krzanich stood on stage at the LA Auto Show and proclaimed, "data is the new oil." This is not a news, of course. For years, tech companies from Google to Facebook have drilled for data shared by connected devices and tapped into geysers of cash. Now that cars are becoming connected, automakers and others want in on the data-for-dollars boom. It's estimated that over 380 million connected cars will be on the road by 2021 globally, more than double the number now. The data they generate will be red meat to marketers since they'll be able to log people's location, driving habits, in-car entertainment choices, and more, while automakers and others will be able to better predict maintenance issues and provide other services to keep customers happy and loyal. The automotive industry is still in the very early stages of figuring out how to cash in on connected car data. Through several partnerships and acquisitions focused on advancing vehicle connectivity and refining data analytics, automotive mega supplier Delphi's recent moves give a glimpse of what the future of driving data collection could look like‚Äîand how automakers could turn massive amounts of car data into big bucks. Delphi recently acquired a minority stake in two Israeli companies. One, Valens, develops chips that can move data up to six times faster within vehicles than current technology. The other, Otonomo, has designed an agnostic data collection platform that can serve as a broker between automakers and third parties. These latest investments in connected car big data solutions are part of a larger and long-term strategy by Delphi. In 2015, the company purchased data-analytics start-up Control-Tec, while earlier this year it acquired Movimento, which provides over-the-air software update capabilities for automotive applications. If you put together the pieces of Delphi's acquisition strategy, it's easy to get a larger picture of where the company‚Äîand the auto industry‚Äîis headed with connected car data. Concrete Example of Leveraging Car Data The Otonomo investment, which was part of a recent $25 million funding round for the start-up, perhaps provides the most concrete example of how automakers could leverage vehicle data and what it means for car owners. Car & Driver noted in an article this week that "what makes [Otonomo's] services attractive to automakers is the ability to aggregate data from multiple companies and provide a more comprehensive data set to interested parties." While automakers such as Ford with its Ford Pass platform and GM with its OnStar AtYourService feature are currently supplying data to third parties in order to offer discounts and perks to drivers, an industrywide data-collecting platform could supercharge the commercial potential of connected cars. Companies ranging from auto insurance companies to roadside retailers would, of course, be eager to buy such connected car data. Related Who Should Control Connected Car Data? Who Should Control Connected Car Data? But car owners may not be so keen to have automakers harvest driving data, and consumer advocacy groups such as AAA as well as politicians have asked automakers for details on how they extract, process, and use driver data. As part of legislation sponsored by Senator Ed Markey (D-Mass.), the federal government would establish standards that not only safeguard driver privacy, but also force the auto industry to be more transparent about how it is used. Delphi noted to Car & Driver that data harvested by Otonomo is anonymized and drivers can opt out of receiving connected services, although the magazine added that this "doesn't mean that drivers who do use those services would have any say in what automakers do with the data those services collect." It also pointed out that since a Republican-led Congress recently voted to roll back FCC restrictions on how ISPs can sell data collected from their customers, Markey's legislation likely has the same possibility of passing as the proverbial snowball's chance in hell. You can bet that Delphi and Otonomo will be followed by other prospectors looking to strike it rich by mining vehicle data. And it's also not too farfetched that, as Otonomo CEO Ben Volkow predicted in a CNN article earlier this year, by 2020 automakers may make more money selling vehicle data than cars themselves. Back to top Previous : Elon Musk Teases Tesla Semi Truck, Pickup By Doug Newcomb Columnist Doug Newcomb is a recognized expert on the subject of car technology within the auto industry and among the automotive and general media, and a frequent speaker at automotive and consumer electronics industry events. Doug began his career in 1988 at the car stereo trade publication Mobile Electronics, before serving as editor of the leading consumer magazines covering the topic, Car Audio and Electronics and Car Stereo Review/Mobile Entertainment/Road & Track Road Gear, from 1989 to 2005. In 2005 Doug started his own company, Newcomb Communications...
